transcripts.text: This video was brought to you by the lovely members of my Patreon.
I don't wish harm or hate on anyone and I just want to make that very very clear.  I'm an imperfect person and I do my best to be caring, kind, and loving and I screw up.

Recently Tati Westbrook uploaded a video where she spoke intimately about how Jeffree Star and Shane Dawson manipulated her into uploading a video a year ago where she accused James Charles of being a sexual predator.
Cracking someone's sexuality is not an escape room.

Now I'll be totally honest.  Tati Westbrook has consistently been one of the few makeup YouTubers that I've had respect for.  She is definitely somebody who is very no nonsense about makeup and that's the kind of beauty influencer that I personally like to follow.  But I will say that I became a little concerned when I started to see Jeffree Star's lipsticks in the background of her videos.  In my mind, Tati has always kind of been this unproblematic YouTuber who is disconnected from the drama of the beauty community.  So I was a little disappointed when I saw her starting to become closer and closer to Jeffree Star and unfortunately it seems that that has not worked out for her.  Now in my previous video, I talked about the leeway that we give creators like Jeffree Star and Shane Dawson, right?  And I also talked about the fact that we're going to see a redemption arc for Shane Dawson, who in my opinion has definitely in comparison to Jeffree Star engaged in what I would say is more extensive and more intense racism.  Now I said this in my Jeffree Star video, but I definitely believe that people can change.  I definitely believe that people, regardless of what they've done or what sort of ideologies they have engaged in, I think that they do have the capacity to change, right?  This truth, right, does not contradict the fact that you don't need to be present for that person's growth.  You don't need to be there to congratulate them for no longer engaging in something like racism.  I think that it is very healthy for people to draw up a boundary and say, you know what?  Maybe you can change.  Maybe you have the capacity to change.  But I'm no longer going to be invested in you as a person or as a creator.  I think that that is healthy and that's something that a lot of people don't tend to acknowledge when we talk about so-called cancel culture.  That drawing lines between yourself and this sort of content is healthy.  It's not weak of you.  to want to withdraw from the content.  that hurts you.  So she talks about a lot in this video and I'll be completely honest, I don't think that she's completely owning up to everything, but that's not really what I wanted to talk about.  I don't really want to talk about Shane or Jeffree Star in this video, even though we've talked about them a couple of times on this channel.  You guys can check out this last video that I made about Shane Dawson if you guys want more of my perspective on this.  What I wanted to focus on in this video was Tatia Westbrook's first public apology to Jackie Aina and kind of what it says about a lot of friendships and relationships between a lot of white people and their black friends or acquaintances.  So I'm going to assume that a lot of you guys watching this have no clue about any of this stuff.  So we're going to go over really quickly a timeline of events.  A few years ago, Jackie Aina made a statement during one of her auntie halls where she said that she would not support Jeffree Star's cosmetics because she's aware of Jeffree Star's anti-black history.

I'm not buying Jeffree Star cosmetics, at least not anytime soon.  I'm not trying to make this open season on anybody.  just being very honest, but I just, I just have a deep issue with the anti-black like comments and things that have been made publicly.

And this public statement got her blocked by Jeffree Star on Instagram.  Then if we fast forward a little bit, David Scissorhands, who is Jeffree Star's former hairstylist and friend did Jackie Aina's hair.  And this obviously set off Jeffree Star.  Now this happened in 2017, but in 2018, David Scissorhands released text messages that showed Jeffree Star referring to Jackie Aina as a gorilla.  Back in 2017, Jeffree Star and Jackie Aina had a very public Twitter fallout where Jeffree Star ultimately called Jackie Aina an irrelevant rat.  So I think it would be an understatement to say that they're not fond of each other.  Now, around the time when they had their Twitter fallout, Tati Westbrook posted a collaboration video with Jeffree Star.  In fact, in her apology, she references this and says that this should have been the moment where she turned her back on Jeffree Star.  but she didn't.  In fact, she would continue to have a relationship with him and would continue to make videos promoting his products.  I wanted to make this video because I saw all of this happen and listening to Tati say what she says about Jackie Aina in this video was kind of hard because I had a hard time justifying how she could say that she's always loved and supported Jackie and has always had a positive relationship with her.  And see how she could feel that way and also still maintain a relationship with Jeffree Star, somebody who is a known racist, who has said and done several things against Jackie Aina that have been clearly a little coded.  And the most that Jackie said was that she wasn't going to promote or support his products because of his previous engagement with anti-blackness, which again, going from my previous video, is a very healthy boundary for her to set.  When there are all of these makeup brands out there, why would you go and support the makeup brand of somebody who has been outwardly and loudly racist, even if they've changed, even if... they've grown.  Of all of the options you have, why Jeffree Star?  And what I wanted to talk about in this video was really how I think for black people, drawing that line is a little bit easier than it is for a lot of white people.

I got it twisted that you had provoked Jeffree because you were angry that I had filmed with someone who had a history of being labeled by others as a racist.  Jackie, I'm sorry that I did not do the right thing and walk away from him then.

Listening to Tati say this triggered a very familiar feeling to me.  That feeling of having a white friend who is hesitant to stand up for you.  Now, contrary to popular belief, I don't personally believe that every white person is a racist.  But what I will say is that I believe pretty much every white person has a relationship with a racist that is more valuable than any relationship they will ever have with a black person.  Now before you get defensive, before you get defensive and say, oh no, no, no, not me.  Think about your racist family members.  Would you cut them off before you cut off your black friend?  Think about your racist partners.  Some of you are sleeping with racists while posting Black Lives Matter on your page.  Would you cut them off quicker than you would cut off your black friend?  Think about it.  Think about it.  I want you to really think critically about this because this is something that I've observed.  People who are friends with me, who have no problem with me, but have these people in their life who engage in racism, who they struggle to let go of.  And I've had these experiences where their friend is saying something racist and I say, Hey man, you're being racist.  And suddenly I'm the asshole.  Suddenly I'm the angry person.  Suddenly I'm the jerk for saying that this racist person who they care about is being racist.  Now I've always had a really hard time understanding why someone would maintain a relationship with somebody who hates the people that they love.  I don't get it.  I personally don't understand it.  But for me, from my observation, it seems like it's very, very hard for a white person to let go of a white person who they are friends with, who they are sleeping with, who is part of their family, who engages in racism.  Now, Jackie Aina, being a black woman, saw Jeffree Star's racism and she still still held out space for him to potentially not be that person anymore.  And when he showed her that he indeed was still that person, she drew the line in the sand.  In fact, she stopped associating with people who supported him.  She stopped working with brands who supported him.  She recently deactivated her code with Morphe because Morphe continues to support and work with Jeffree Star.  and who these companies continue to support and work with definitely speaks volumes.  And that's what I really wanted to talk about in this video.  Look, you might not be racist, of course not, you're one of the good ones, right?  But the relationships that you choose to maintain with the people who hurt the people whom you claim to support really does express where you stand.  Tati said in her video that Jeffree Star was like a lion.  He was dangerous, but he was always nice to her.  And I found that to be really interesting.  So yeah, maybe he's racist or whatever, but he's nice to me, so... There's just something about hearing that out loud that really cuts a little too deep.  Her saying that basically affirmed the point that at the time her relationship with Jeffree star was more important than her relationship with Jackie Aina, which frankly boggles my mind because when it comes to aesthetics and you know, people who are in, your sort of realm of makeup.  Jackie Aina and Tati Westbrook are obviously in the same category.  They do a very similar type of makeup for a very similar type of girl.  And Jeffree Star is just so outside of the aesthetic realm that it's strange to me that she wouldn't want to foster a productive, healthy relationship with Jackie Aina, who is clearly way more in her realm.  But let's be honest for a second.  Jeffree Star can do more for Tati Westbrook than Jackie Aina ever could.  Jeffree Star is mega rich.  He's mega famous.  He's got 18 million subscribers on YouTube.  A relationship with Jeffree Star is more beneficial to Tati Westbrook than it would have been for her to maintain a relationship with Jackie Aina.  While Jackie Aina is a powerhouse in her own right, she doesn't quite have the same amount of reach or power as Jeffree Star.  Now, it shouldn't surprise you that as a black girl who wears makeup that I am a huge Jackie Aina stan.  And one of the things that I've always appreciated about Jackie Aina is how she holds onto her faith.  Now, I'm an atheist.  I don't believe in any of it.  But I've always respected the fact that in a time where being religious is becoming less and less popular, that Jackie Aina stuck to her guns.  That she still puts Bible verses in the descriptions of her videos and sometimes even in the videos.  that she's always held on to God and always been a religious person.  I think that's beautiful even if I don't believe it.  Part of holding on to your faith is doing what is unpopular because it's godly.  It's remaining steadfast in your walk with God while everyone around you sins.  It's having integrity.  And what's clear to me while watching Tati Westbrook's video is that she greatly lacks integrity.  Now in her video, Tati Westbrook says that she is a woman of faith.  So I wanted to read her a Bible verse.  1 Timothy 6.10 says, Tati valued money over integrity.  And that's why she maintained a relationship with Jeffree Star, somebody who screams ungodliness and unrepentant sin.  Of course it is the Christian thing to do to see the best in others, but I think it's important to point out that Tati Westbrook did more than just try to see the best in Jeffree and try to make him a role model and et cetera, et cetera.  She suspended her disbelief to the point where she looked at his racism and gave him so much more support than she's ever given Jackie Aina.  If you go to her channel right now, you will not find a single time where she has supported anything that Jackie Aina has put out in terms of makeup.  She's reviewed pretty much every Anastasia Beverly Hills palette except for hers.  But meanwhile, there are several, several videos of her supporting Jeffree Star's product releases.  And those videos are still available for you to watch right now on her channel even though she just made... An apology video saying that Jeffree Star manipulated her.  Tati Westbrook tries to really minimize her relationship with Jeffree Star in her video by saying that they weren't even close like that.  But even still, she still went out of her way to promote his products.  And I think that it's worth talking about why that is, why the racism wasn't enough.  I think it says a lot that the accusations of racism weren't enough for Tati Westbrook to be like, yeah, no, I don't need to work with that person.  I think that there was so much suspension of disbelief, so much leeway, so much consideration.  And it's a degree of consideration that Jackie Aina wasn't given at all.  Jackie Aina was just dismissed as some angry, bitter black girl who was mad that she didn't have as many subscribers or wasn't as loved as Jeffree Star was.  But Jeffree Star could go into the middle of the street and say, heinously racist things and get just an endless amount of support, concern and consideration.  Four months ago, Jackie Aina did what Tati Westbrook didn't do and she supported her release.  Jackie Aina made a video reviewing Tati Westbrook's new palette and her makeup sponge and she gave it a raving review.

Tati reached out to me and said some really heartfelt things and really truly made me feel like she was sincere in trying to start over and mend something with me and like I really appreciated that.  Tati, I'm not gonna put all of that out there, but I thought that was worth mentioning.

It'll always be interesting and depressing to me that people will sooner defend a racist reputation than they will stand up against racism.  What I ultimately wanted to communicate in this video is that your black friends see you do this.  You know, you may think that your black friend, you know, just doesn't notice you bending over backwards to justify your relationship with a racist, but we see it.  And the more we see it and the more you do it, the less we trust you.  Personally, I don't have racist or transphobic or misogynistic or homophobic or any kind of phobic friends because life is too short. I think that she is taking more and more accountability and that is great.  I love that she is acknowledging how her actions have negatively impacted others.  I hope that she continues to move forward in a positive direction.  And as time goes on, she can become a more and more trustworthy friend.  Anyway, that is all I had to say about this.
